response: The image depicts the Potential Tropical Cyclone Three Advisory Number 5 from the National Hurricane Center at 400 PM CDT on Friday, June 18, 2021. It describes a system centered near latitude 27.9 North, longitude 91.2 West, about 125 miles (200 km) south of Morgan City, Louisiana and about 270 miles (430 km) west-southwest of Mobile, Alabama. Maximum sustained winds are near 45 mph (75 km/h), with higher gusts. The system is moving toward the north near 16 mph (26 km/h) and is forecast to make landfall along the north-central Gulf Coast tonight or early Saturday, with a northeastward or east-northeastward motion across the southeastern United States through the weekend. Heavy rainfall totals of 4 to 8 inches with isolated maximum amounts of 12 inches are expected across portions of the Central Gulf Coast, and flash, urban and small stream flooding impacts as well as new and renewed minor to isolated moderate river flooding are likely. Storm surge and tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. Tropical storm conditions are beginning to reach the coast within the warning area, and these winds will continue into Saturday. A few tornadoes are possible on Saturday across southern portions of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and the western Florida Panhandle. The next intermediate advisory is at 700 PM CDT, and the next complete advisory is at 1000 PM CDT.
The port of Charleston, SC is most likely to begin experiencing tropical storm conditions on Friday afternoon.
Flooding from heavy rain may cause disruptions to port operations, including delays or closures of the container terminals.
